entries.meaning: A force compounded by means of a lever rotating around a pivot; see torque.
examples: A crowbar uses leverage to pry nails out of wood.

entries.meaning: (by extension) Any influence which is compounded or used to gain an advantage.
examples: Try using competitors’ prices for leverage in the negotiation.

entries.meaning: (finance) The use of borrowed funds with a contractually determined return to increase the ability to invest and earn an expected higher return, but usually at high risk.
examples: Leverage is great until something goes wrong with your investments and you still have to pay your debts.

entries.meaning: (business) The ability to earn very high returns when operating at high-capacity utilization of a facility.
examples: Their variable-cost-reducing investments have dramatically increased their leverage.

verbs.description: leverage (third-person singular simple present leverages, present participle leveraging, simple past and past participle leveraged)

entries.meaning: (transitive, chiefly US, slang, business) To use; to exploit; to manipulate in order to take full advantage (of something).
examples: They plan to leverage the publicity into a good distribution agreement.
They plan to leverage off the publicity to get a good distribution agreement.
